I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 

 
1. 
to the Kingdom of Tonga for the Integrated Urban Resilience Sector Project. 
 
The project will provide high-priority urban infrastructure identified in the Tonga National 
2. 
Infrastructure  Investment  Plan,1  expanding  on  infrastructure  development  being  undertaken  in 
Nuku’alofa  through  the  ongoing  Nuku’alofa  Urban  Development  Sector  Project  (NUDSP),2 
enhancing  the  delivery  of  public  urban  services,  and  building  climate  change  and  disaster 
resilience. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Urban  growth  and  development  pressure.  Tonga’s  total  population  is  estimated  at 
100,651.3 Nearly three-quarters of Tonga’s population resides on the main island of Tongatapu, 
and 80% of the island’s population and infrastructure are located in low-lying coastal areas. This 
includes the capital, Nuku’alofa. The greater Nuku’alofa area comprises 6,134 households with a 
total  population  of  35,184,  and  this  is  forecasted  to grow  to  45,000 (or  about  40%  of  Tonga's 
population)  by  2030.  Migration  to  Nuku’alofa  from  Tonga's  outer  islands  is  significant.4  Urban 
growth in Tonga is a relatively recent phenomenon and has not been matched by the provision 
or  improvement  in  the  delivery  of  urban  services.  Living  conditions  for  many  of  Nuku’alofa’s 
residents are deteriorating and demand for improved urban infrastructure is increasing. Sustained 
urban growth has put pressure on the availability of urban land. Expansion in the capital is limited 
by  peripheral  agricultural  and  ecologically  sensitive  areas,  placing  development  pressure  on 
existing marginal areas. Some of these areas are below high tide levels and therefore experience 
frequent coastal inundation. 
 
4. 
Climate  change  and  natural  hazards.  Natural  hazards  and  climate  change  pose  a 
significant  threat  to  Tonga.  The  archipelagic  country  is  located  in  the  Pacific  cyclone  belt  and 
intense  seismic  activity  also  occurs.  In  addition,  most  of  its  atoll  islands  are  very  flat,  with  an 
average height of 2–5 meters above sea level. As a result, Tonga—and Nuku’alofa—are highly 
exposed  to  sea-level  rise,  storm  surge,  and  tsunami  inundation.  Critical  infrastructure  and 
services and more than 10,000 buildings are located in low-lying Nuku’alofa. Consequently, the 
entire  country’s  economic  and  operational  vulnerability  to  natural  hazards,  such  as  tsunami, 
floods, and cyclones, is extreme. The World Risk Report points out that, despite the growth in 
Tonga’s  income  and  development  level,  the  country’s  vulnerability  to  natural  hazards  has  not 
decreased.5 In fact, all vulnerability indicators increased slightly during 2012–2016. 

 

5. 
Susceptibility to flooding. Rain-fed floods have affected Nuku’alofa’s urban area more 
than any  other  type  of  natural  hazards  in terms of frequency  and  number  of  people impacted. 
Tropical  cyclones  and  storm  surges  frequently  force  hundreds  of  households  be  relocated  to 
community evacuation centers as their houses are submerged in flood. There is high certainty 
that the frequency and intensity of extreme rainfall events will increase due to climate change,

 Nuku’alofa’s flooding problems will likely worsen if no significant measures are taken.6 As the poor 
communities usually live in the flood prone areas, they suffer more from flooding. Waterlogging 
with  poor  sanitation  also  increases  incidence  of  typhoid,  diarrhea,  and  skin  diseases.  The 
stagnant water will introduce more mosquito, leading to more vectorborne diseases. There are 
also gender impacts of flooding as women have caring responsibilities (as a result of health risks), 
and are primarily responsible for household maintenance. 
 
6. 
Due to climate change, the greatest long-term threat to Nuku’alofa is sea-level rise, which 
will  lead  to  permanent  sea  water  inundation  in  low-lying  areas.  The  initial  impacts  are  already 
observed. In the low-lying districts of Popua and Sopu,7 rising sea levels have led to inundation 
during spring tides and storm surges. By 2100, mean sea level is projected to be approximately 
1 meter higher than present under an RCP8.5 scenario,8 so most of Nuku’alofa area will lie below 
sea level. However, the flat terrain of Nuku’alofa limits engineering options to mitigate flooding, 
and in areas where trunk channels might be effective, mitigating flooding beyond once-in-2-year 
frequency would require significantly wider channels. The unavailability of land to accommodate 
wider channel systems raise additional challenges. 
 
Because  of  these  challenges,  a  citywide  flood  management  system  is  not  viable  at 
7. 
present. However, some infrastructure and nature-based solutions should be implemented in the 
short  to  medium  term  to  minimize  the  flooding  in  the  city.  These  solutions  would  focus  on 
economically important roads and areas particularly the central business district and lower-lying 
areas based on criteria of (i) the bigger number of properties and benefited catchment areas, (ii) 
the  higher  flood  level  reduction  associated  with  the  proposed  works,  and  (iii)  the  less  land 
requirement of privately leased or owned land. 
 
8. 
Sanitation. Most households are served by septic tanks which used to be desludged only 
when full or overflowing. Septic tanks could be the main source of contaminants in aquifers in the 
Nuku’alofa area.9 The availability of septic tank desludge trucks, together with increased public 
awareness of environment, has created a significant increase in septage cleaning and collection. 
However, septage sludge treatment facility in Tapuhia has the capacity of 10,000 liters per day, 
which  would  treat  only  up  to  74%  of  the  households  and  commercial  septage  generated  in 
Nuku’alofa, it should be augmented to allow regular desludging of all septic tanks and to treat the 
landfill leachate.  
 
Solid waste management. The  state-owned enterprise  of the Waste  Authority  Limited 
9. 
(WAL) does the waste management in Tongatapu. The government has expanded its operation 
to cover all of the outer islands in the next few years. This expansion will place an extra demand 
on the only safe disposal facility of the Tapuhia Waste Management Facility (TWMF) until other 
safe disposal facility is constructed. TWMF current landfill cell will be fulfilled in 2023 based on 
the demand.10 Adequate solid waste collection and disposal helps to minimize the flood risk by 
reducing the waste blocking of the drains. Furthermore, in the urban and semi-urban communities 
around TWMF, public demand of a clean environment requires TWMF to upgrade its operation. 
Therefore,  TWMF’s operation and capacity should be upgraded to meet the requirements.

 10.  Water  supply.  Supported  by  NUDSP,  since  2015,  potable  water  supply  coverage  in 
Nuku’alofa area has reached 100%. However, due to the part of old water system, nonrevenue 
water (NRW) is estimated to be 45%. 41% of households have reported issues of water pressure 
and 19% experienced with water service interruptions. 11 NUDSP implements zoning of the water 
supply system, which allows water district to be isolated, and identify problem areas for repairing. 
Upon commissioning of the new zoning network, a monitoring program should be put in place as 
well as a network upgrade plan to identify priority areas for rehabilitation. Because the RCP8.5 
scenario  estimates  that  the  average  duration  and  frequency  of  droughts  in  Tongatapu  would 
increase  substantially  impacting  the  availability  of  the  water  resource  in  Nuku’alofa,  the  NRW 
management will save precious water resource as well as energy consumption,  
 
11. 
Asset  management.  Management  of  existing  and  new  urban  infrastructure  is  a  high 
priority.  Government  policy  is  that  the  cost  of  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  of  utility 
infrastructure should be funded from user charges. The government intends to work closely with 
public enterprises, the private sector, and development partners to lift the overall performance of 
the public utility sector and to achieve self-funding of sustainable O&M. However, not all public 
utility enterprises have developed and implemented asset management frameworks and plans.  
Among them, Tonga Water  Board  (TWB)  and WAL  need  strong support to  continue the  asset 
management plan developed by NUDSP to ensure the service sustainability.  
 
12. 
Value  added  by  ADB  assistance  and lessons  learnt.  The  Asian  Development  Bank 
(ADB) has been one of the major development institutions supporting the development of urban 
infrastructure and improvement of urban services in Nuku’alofa, and has relevant experience and 
knowledge  of the  sector.12  This  project  is the  third in  a  series  of  ADB  investments  and  capacity 
building activities in Nuku’alofa’s urban sector which commenced in 2008,13 and it expands critical 
investments of NUDSP but not limited by sanitation, waste management and water supply. Lessons 
learned from previous investments have be incorporated in the project design, which enhances  the 
long  term  asset  management  plans  to  ensure  the  service  sustainability  and  provides  technical 
solutions to address long standing issues such as NRW and flooding. Due to the limit of the funding, 
the previous projects address the most urgent and specific urban requirements as water supply and 
waste management. This project has considered not only short-term urban development priorities 
but  also  initiation  of  activities  to  adapt  to  the  significant  long-term  climate  change  impacts  on 
Nuku’alofa in a holistic method. For the first time, the project will manage the nexus of solid waste, 
flood, and waste water to ensure the comprehensive benefit in urban area. It also allows the start 
of a longer-term policy dialogue with the government on user’ charges and O&M plan. The project 
is  in  line  with  ADB  Strategy  2030,  highlighting  the  differentiated  approach  to  small  island 
developing  states,  specifically  focusing  the  operational  priorities  3,  4  and  6:  tackling  climate 
change,  building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability; 
making cities more livable; and strengthening governance and institutional capacity.14

Outputs 

Impacts and Outcome 

The National Spatial Planning and Management Act, prepared under the NUDSP and approved 
by  the  government,  will  provide  the  framework  for  planning  and  coordinating  urban  sector 
development. The selection criteria of the subprojects are outlined in the project administration 
manual (PAM)16 and safeguards frameworks have been developed during project preparation to 
cater to this modality. 
 
B. 
 
14. 
The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impacts:  (i)  living  standards  in  Nuku’alofa 
improved, and (ii) resilience to existing extreme natural events and to the threat of climate change 
increased.17  The  project  will  have  the  following  outcome:  Nuku’alofa  residents  have  access  to 
improved, effective, and climate-resilient urban services and infrastructure.18 
 
C. 
 
15. 
Output  1:  Effective flood  risk management infrastructure implemented.  To reduce 
flood  risk,  the  project  will  rehabilitate  and  provide  new  flood  management  and  drainage 
infrastructure  at  seven  flood-prone  locations  throughout  Nuku’alofa,  comprising  the  central 
business district, Vuna road, Salote road, Fanga, Haveluloto, Tofoa, and Sopu.19 The project will 
also  assist  the  Ministry  of  Infrastructure  to  review  the  current  Land  Transport  Division  funding 
arrangements and to prepare and implement a review of tariff structures and charges to achieve 
and maintain full recovery of O&M costs for public flood management and drainage infrastructure. 
The project will also assist the Land Transport Division to prepare a 10-year asset management 
plan; provide capacity-building support to operate, repair, and maintain the new drainage network; 
and strengthen revenue collection and asset management. 
 
Output  2:  Water  supply  service  in  Nuku’alofa  improved.  The  project  will  reduce 
16. 
nonrevenue water through the rehabilitation and upgrade of Nuku’alofa’s piped water distribution 
network and by improving TWB leak detection, monitoring, repair, and maintenance capabilities. 
The  project  will  also  improve  the  TWB’s  service  capacities  by  providing  new  field  testing 
equipment and vehicles and building capacity to use water supply models and field data to guide 
the planning and implementation of pipe distribution network upgrades. The project will also carry 
out  a gender-sensitive  review  of  the  current TWB  tariff  structures  and charges to achieve and 
maintain full recovery of O&M costs while maintaining community service obligations. The project 
will also assist the TWB to prepare a 10-year asset management plan and to develop policies and 
processes to support women in the workplace. 
 
17. 
Output  3:  Public  and  environmental  health  enhanced.  The  project  will  enhance 
septage  and  solid-waste  management  and  collection  in  Tongatapu  by  upgrading  the  Tapuhia 
septage  and  leachate  wastewater  treatment  plant;  constructing  a  new  sanitary  landfill  cell; 
providing  a  new  office  and  a  mechanical  servicing  facility  at  Tapuhia  sanitary  landfill;  and 
procuring essential plant and equipment to expand waste operations, including waste collection 
trucks that will allow women to work as waste collectors for the first time. The project will assist 
WAL  to  improve  its  financial  management  capacity  and  will  review  the  current  WAL  tariff 
structures and charges to achieve and maintain full recovery of O&M costs while ensuring that 
waste  services  are  affordable  and  accessible  to  the  poorest  members  of  the  community. 
Considering WAL is mandated to expand its operations to the outer islands, the project will assist 
WAL  to  explore  possible  economically  and  environmentally  sustainable  solutions  for  waste 
management in the outer islands, including the shipping of waste to Tapuhia. The project will also

 III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Economic and Financial 

 
A. 
 
22. 
The project is found to be economically viable, with an overall economic internal rate of 
return of 9.3% and economic net present value of $0.2 million; the water supply and sanitation 
subprojects  are  also  estimated  to  yield  returns  higher  than  the  9.0%  threshold.  The  flood 
management  subproject  is  not  viable  on  its  own  but  is  integral  to  ensuring  urban  resilience  in 
Tonga as it is seen to reduce flooding incidence and thus the costs of post-flood repairs for both 
households and businesses. The water supply subproject will cut losses from leakage and faulty 
metering,  increasing  the  local  supply  and  improving  cost  recovery.  Finally,  the  sanitation 
subproject  is  expected  to bring  significant  health  benefits  by  reducing  exposure  to waterborne 
diseases.  The  water  supply  and  sanitation  subprojects  remain  economically  viable  under  all 
adverse  scenarios.  All  subprojects  appear  most  sensitive  to  increases  in  investment  costs  or 
reductions in benefits, but these are not seen to be major concerns. 
 
23. 
Individual financial evaluations of the revenue-generating subprojects find only the water 
supply subproject to be viable on its own, with a financial internal rate of return of 3.9% (versus a 
3.0%  discount  rate)  and  financial  net  present  value  of  $177,856.  However,  the  sanitation 
subproject is expected to be financially sustainable as WAL is seen to expand its services to more 
customers, and earn enough revenues to fund the operation and maintenance of project assets. 
A  tariff  review  planned  under  this  project  should  help  implementing  agencies  achieve  cost 
recovery and explore options for optimal user charges; public consultations and the planned work 
in the water, sanitation, and hygiene awareness should improve public understanding of the need 
for  sustainable  water  and  sanitation  services.  The  non-revenue-generating  flood  management 
subproject is likewise seen to be financially sustainable because historical increases in the budget 
allocations to the Ministry of Infrastructure-Land Transport Division suggest that enough additional 
funds will be made available to support operation and maintenance expenses for project assets, 
which are forecast to be only a small part of the total budget. In both cases, the grant agreement 
assures  financial  sustainability  of  project  assets  as  detailed  in  para.  20  above.  The  Pacific 
Disaster Resilience Program 20 would also provide financial support, especially in times of disaster 
or emergency. 
 
B. 
 
A financial management assessment for the project was conducted in August 2018.21 The 
24. 
assessment considered the MOF as the executing agency and the MLNR as the implementing 
agency, including funds-flow arrangements, staffing, accounting and financial reporting systems, 
financial  information  systems,  and  internal  and  external  auditing  arrangements.  The  financial 
management capacity of the MOF, based on the public expenditure and financial accountability 
assessment and from being the executing agency for other ADB-funded projects, is considered 
adequate.  The  MLNR  has  the  capacity  and  experience,  demonstrated  through  being  the 
implementing agency for the ongoing NUDSP, and it is proposed that the advance account and 
statement  of  expenditures  procedure  be  used.  The  overall  inherent  and  project  financial 
management risk assessment is considered moderate, given that a new project management unit 
(PMU) will be set up and the new staff will be trained on ADB’s disbursement, financial reporting, 
and auditing requirements. A key mitigating measure will be to ensure that a dedicated full-time 
project  accountant  supports  the  PMU  in  the  MLNR.  The  MOF  and  MLNR  have  agreed  to 
implement an action plan as key measures to address the deficiencies. Financial management 
risks and risk mitigation measures will be reviewed and updated throughout the life of the project.

Poverty, Social, and Gender 

ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the 
government and particularly with the MOF. The specific policy requirements and supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 16). 
 
C. 
 
25. 
The poverty and social analysis notes that there is an increasing trend towards migration 
from rural to urban areas for better access to social services and income opportunities. In the last 
decade this has resulted in rapid urban population growth in Nuku’alofa, which has put pressure 
on urban infrastructure perpetuating hardship in relation to a lack of access to quality essential 
services. In this context, specific groups most vulnerable to hardship live in areas with recurrent 
floods or perpetual standing water, and are also vulnerable to natural hazards, poor sanitation 
conditions,  and  deficient  water  supply.  The  project  aims  to  improve  living  standards, 
environmental management, and urban development by fostering equitable, reliable, and quality 
water and waste management services, as well as improve resilience to climate change risk. 
 
26. 
This project is classified as effective gender mainstreaming. In the project sites, women 
are concerned about (i) affordability of services such as water, (ii) improvement of health and well-
being  of  households,  (iii)  opportunities  for  income  generation,  and  (iv)  ensuring  women’s 
involvement in consultation and decision-making. The overall project will provide indirect benefits 
to women, including improving health and well-being of households, and reducing pressure on 
women’s  time  (because  of  lack  of  reliable  and  quality  water  supply  and  the  need  to  manage 
impacts of flooding and poor sanitation, e.g., household maintenance, health issues, and caring 
responsibilities). In addition, a gender action plan has been prepared with proactive gender design 
features, including (i) a gender-sensitive tariff review; (ii) income-generating activities, including 
long-term employment opportunities for women in nontraditional roles such as flood management 
infrastructure workers, plumbers, meter readers, and waste collectors; (iii) increasing women’s 
participation  in  decision-making  at  the  community,  institutional,  and  national  levels  through 
ensuring participation of women and girls in the water, sanitation, and hygiene committees; (iv) 
supporting  the  TWB  to  develop  a  gender  strategy  to  support  more  women  in  the  workplace, 
particularly  in  technical  and  management  roles;  and  (v)  ensuring  that  gender  analysis  and 
recommendations are included in the climate- and disaster-resilient urban development strategy 
and  the  community-based  disaster  risk  management  program.22  A  social  development  and 
gender specialist will be engaged in the PMU to assist the MLNR in implementing and monitoring 
the gender action plan and supporting activities under the plan.
